prompt: An auto parts plant in Toledo installs 'productivity wearables' that track arm movements to the millisecond. The data shows that an older, beloved shift foreman is 15% slower than the new hires, but his error rate is zero. The algorithm automatically flags him for a 'performance improvement plan' that is the first step to termination. Do you override the system?

A union organizer in a Michigan stamping plant discovers that management is using heat-mapping data from the factory Wi-Fi to identify where workers congregate for more than 3 minutes, effectively predicting and breaking up union talks before they start. Is this a safety measure or illegal surveillance?

A Kenosha logistics center implements an AI scheduling system that maximizes efficiency but systematically schedules single mothers for 'flex shifts' that make childcare impossible to secure. The company claims the algorithm is 'gender neutral' based purely on demand availability.

A historic steel mill in Ohio introduces 'Cobots' (collaborative robots) to work alongside humans. The sensors record every conversation within a 10-foot radius 'for training purposes.' Workers realize the recordings are being accessed by HR to adjudicate disputes in the breakroom.

During a severe blizzard in Minnesota, a warehouse algorithm automatically fires 15 employees for failing to meet pick-rates because delivery trucks couldn't arrive. The local manager knows reinstatement requires a corporate appeal process that takes weeks, leaving families without pay in winter.

A manufacturing company offers free Fitbits to lower health insurance premiums for workers. It turns out the data is being sold to a third-party actuary to adjust rates for the entire county based on the aggregate health of the workforce, penalizing the whole town.

An Indiana RV manufacturer uses eye-tracking cameras to monitor driver fatigue in their delivery fleet. The system flags drivers who wear prescription bifocals as 'distracted' due to head tilt, threatening the jobs of the most experienced drivers.

A gig-economy delivery platform enters a mid-sized Wisconsin city, undercutting local courier services. They refuse to share the data on how 'surge pricing' is calculated, leading local drivers to suspect the algorithm is artificially inflating prices to kill off local competition before raising rates.

A third-generation Iowa corn farmer fixes a sensor on his tractor himself to beat the rain. The manufacturer's software detects the 'unauthorized repair' and bricks the tractor remotely during harvest. He has to hack his own equipment to save the crop.

A seed conglomerate offers free precision-ag software to Minnesota soybean farmers. The fine print says the company owns the yield data. They use this data to buy up the most productive land in the county through shell companies, outbidding the local families who generated the data.

A dairy co-op implements automated milking machines. The vendor requires a permanent internet connection to 'optimize' the milk flow. When the rural broadband goes down for three days, the machines lock out, causing a health crisis for the herd.

Drone surveillance by a major ag-tech firm flies over private fields in Illinois to detect if farmers are saving patented seeds from the previous year. A farmer shoots down a drone hovering over his house, claiming privacy violation; the company sues for destruction of property.

An AI pricing model for a regional grain elevator sets prices based on global futures and local satellite imagery. It predicts a neighbor's crop failure before he knows it, offering him a predatory low price for his remaining yield. Do you warn him?

Soil sensors placed by a university extension program identify a rare mineral deposit on a struggling family farm. The data is technically public. Do researchers publish it, knowing mining companies will pressure the family to sell their heritage?

A vertical farming startup in Chicago wants to partner with rural farmers for 'carbon credits,' paying them to not plant certain fields. The contract requires installing sensors that track all movement on the property to verify compliance, effectively surveilling the farm family's daily life.

Cattle electronic ear tags are introduced to track disease. The database is hacked, and the specific location and value of prize winning herds are leaked to a ring of cattle rustlers targeting high-value livestock in the Dakotas.

A national telecom provider refuses to run fiber to a 'hollow' in West Virginia/Ohio border because the ROI algorithm says the population density is too low. The town wants to build its own municipal broadband, but the telecom lobbies the state legislature to ban community-owned ISPs.

The only local newspaper in a Michigan county is bought by a hedge fund and replaced by an AI that scrapes police blotters to generate 'news.' The AI publishes an arrest record for a man who was later exonerated, destroying his reputation in the small town.

A 'Smart City' grant offers a Rust Belt town free pothole repair in exchange for installing streetlights with facial recognition cameras. The town council needs the road money but fears turning Main Street into a surveillance state.

A tight-knit neighborhood uses a Ring camera network. The footage is automatically shared with police without a warrant. A neighbor's camera catches a teen sneaking out for a secret relationship, and the 'community safety' group exposes them, causing a family crisis.

A Wisconsin tourist town is hollowed out by an algorithm used by property investors to buy up starter homes for Airbnb rentals. The algorithm predicts which houses will list before they hit the market, making it impossible for locals to buy homes.

A library in a conservative district is pressured to install filtering software to protect children. The software's 'obscenity' filter automatically blocks health sites regarding breast cancer and LGBTQ support groups, cutting off vital information for isolated residents.

An app designed to report 'suspicious activity' in a suburb becomes a hub for racial profiling against delivery drivers and utility workers. The moderator, a respected community elder, refuses to delete the posts, citing 'free speech' and 'neighborhood watch' traditions.

A utility company installs smart meters that can detect specific appliance usage. They use this data to fine residents for using space heaters during peak hours, disproportionately affecting the elderly who can't afford to upgrade their insulation.

A rural church adopts an online tithing app. The app developer sells the donor list to political action committees, and congregants start receiving targeted attack ads based on their donation amounts. The pastor feels he betrayed his flock's trust.

During a livestreamed funeral service, the platform's copyright bot mutes the audio because the choir sang a copyrighted hymn. The remote family members miss the eulogy. Does the church break the law to pirate the stream for the next service?

A youth pastor uses a location-tracking app for a teen retreat 'for safety.' He forgets to turn it off after the trip and inadvertently tracks a teen visiting a Planned Parenthood clinic. He now faces a dilemma of confidentiality vs. parental notification.

An aging congregation installs facial recognition to help the new pastor remember names. The system starts logging attendance and automatically sends 'we missed you' emails to absentees, making the church feel like a debt collector rather than a community.
A mega-church moves into a small town and uses 'geofencing' to target ads to phones inside the historic local chapels on Sunday mornings. The local pastors view this as digital sheep-stealing.

A pastor admits to using ChatGPT to write his sermons because he is burned out visiting sick parishioners. The sermons are popular, but the deacons feel the 'Holy Spirit' has been outsourced to an algorithm.

A church runs a digital 'prayer wall.' A scraper bot harvests the names and health struggles posted by members to build profiles for scam callers claiming to be hospital administrators demanding payment.

An Amish community is pressured by the state to install digital turn signals on their buggies for safety on high-speed roads. They refuse on religious grounds, but the data shows a 40% reduction in accidents with the tech. How does the state balance safety vs. religious freedom?

A rural school district accepts free Chromebooks that require Google account tracking. The only internet access for many students is a 4G hotspot that filters content. A student researching hunting rifles for a 4-H project is flagged as a 'violence risk' and suspended.

To save money on busing, a district uses an algorithm to optimize routes. The new route forces farm kids to be on the bus for 2 hours each way, meaning they can't do chores. The algorithm says it's 'optimal,' but the family farm economy relies on that labor.

An AI grading system is implemented to help overworked teachers. It consistently marks down essays written in AAVE (African American Vernacular English) or rural dialects as 'grammatically poor,' forcing students to code-switch to pass, erasing their cultural voice.

A high school football team in Ohio uses biometric helmet sensors to track impact. The star quarterback takes a hit that registers as a concussion risk, but he feels fine. The coach wants to override the sensor to win the state championship game.

A school implements 'E-Learning Days' for snow days. 30% of the students live in areas with no broadband. The school suggests they sit in the McDonald's parking lot to do homework. Is this an equitable education policy?

A third-party lunch payment system tracks what students eat. They propose selling this data to the parents' health insurance providers to 'incentivize healthy choices,' effectively raising premiums for families who rely on the cheaper, processed school lunch options.

A wealthy suburban district donates their old iPads to a poor rural district. The iPads are still locked to the donor's management system, meaning the rural admin can't install local apps. The donor district refuses to unlock them citing 'security policies.'

Classroom management software allows teachers to view the screens of students at all times. A teacher notices a student is writing a suicide note in a private Google Doc during class. Does she intervene immediately, revealing she was spying, or follow standard counseling protocol?
